127872758.review:
It's a great co-op game and series. Totally worth your time. We Were Here Forever is the 4th game in the series, but you can play it without ever playing previous ones (I won't recommend though if you're interested in lore). 

Game has asymmetric gameplay, puzzles are based on communication between you and your co-op partner as each of you has only half of the puzzle. You need to let other know what you see and can do to figure out the task and help each other to finish it. And believe me, devs tried to make puzzles as challenging as it was possible.

Compared to other co-op room escape games this one focuses more on your coordination. Puzzle itself could be not that hard, but explaining to each other what you see and combine knowledge to solve the problem is a tricky part.

Compared to previous games in this series puzzles become noticably harder and require more talking to explain and making sense out of hints. Game also lost a lot of replayability as more puzzles have scripted solutions instead of being randomized. Appearance of several timed puzzles which require coordinated timed input from you both also added to the level of the challenge. But everything was possible to figure out, so we greatly enjoyed this ecperience.

Technically game is also better optimized than previous ones in the series. There were no crushes this time and "surprize" levels where fps dropped to zero because of additional details on it.

Can't wait for the next game!^.~

134426636.review:
[h1]Together Forever[/h1]
Having a tradition of writing a review for every title from the We Were Here franchise, I would do this game a huge injustice if I have skipped it. Especially given that Forever is, without a shadow of a doubt, the best of the series. The biggest, the most complicated and by far the most expensive of all four games, We Were Here Forever takes you on one (and probably last) adventure. But is it worth it? 
You can bet your ass it is. There really are no obvious flaws that I could talk about. This game is simply great and you should buy it. Without hesitation, if you happen to have a friend or a loved one up for some logical puzzles. Hell, even with internet strangers this game might be one hell of an experience.

[h1]In awe at the size of this lad[/h1]
I am honestly astounded by how far this game series has come. It’s mind-boggling that something that used to be a tiny free game to be completed in one sitting has become a giant, highly-polished product which gives so much content it is difficult to overstate how fun it can be.
The very first thing I have to note is that from previous experiences with We Were Here games, both myself and my mate Alvarion who I had a pleasure of playing all four titles with, expected this game to be short. Or at least short-ER. Short enough to complete it with one, monstrous 8h sitting. Maybe 10-12 hours if need be. Needless to say, we weren’t even close. It took us well over 14 hours to complete the title for the first time. [b]And that’s worth a praise.[/b] Because literally at no point was the game boring or time wasted. No, it was a blast through and throughout this many hours. It’s a puzzle game with an enormous number of things to do in it. We Were Here Forever is an absolute unit. There is just a puzzle, after a puzzle, after a puzzle and it really doesn’t seem to end until you really are reaching the conclusion of the story. 

One thing that you might want to take away from this is… I’m not saying you [i]can’t[/i] complete WWHF in one sitting. There is a certain threshold after which that fragile pink mass hidden within your skull cavity starts giving up. I think we have reached our maximum brain capacities at 6 hours mark on the first day. With logic games you should really watch out for that. Cause there is a moment in which you become tired of playing, no matter how fun the title is. Keeping a high level of focus necessary to solve complex puzzles gets more and more difficult as the time goes on. Take my advice, go for short or longer breaks after each chapter to come back fresh and be the best “you” you can be.

Having that in mind, the developers neatly divided the game into chapters. Each of them consists of a couple of themed puzzles. To give you a better look into the world of We Were Here, every puzzle also presents some narrative elements. Big enough for you to notice how tied to the game world each puzzle is, small enough to let you go to the bathroom without worrying of losing an important piece of storytelling. 

Speaking of storytelling – the story that was first hinted in We Were Here, then shyly expanded in We Were Here Too, and then pushed to something I could call an actual piece of narrative in We Were Here Together, and is FINALLY focused on in Forever. Merely speaking of it could be too revealing so let me just tell you what I think about it.
It's good. It’s nothing groundbreaking but it does make sense. It ties the previous games together and gives you more information about the lore behind all those events. Total Mayhem Games was not scared to put a short cinematic cutscene between each chapter and then create a great visual finale before and after the actual story climax. It was a great decision because nothing seems out of place anymore while still keeping that elusive masquerade of not telling you everything.

[h1]Use your brain[/h1]
Something I should perhaps touch on is the game’s difficulty level. [i]Well? What is it, Tank?[/i]
I’m gonna say… it’s perfectly balanced. For the first time in the series.
What do I mean by that?

There are multiple puzzles to go through, from matching shapes, through describing sounds, playing spot the difference, planning routes, placing things in correct spaces to doing all of these things in correct order under the pressure of time. And it’s fantastic. This is the first game in the series, where Alvarion and I made a list of puzzles we liked and disliked each and while our lists varied… we were never like [i]“this one thing sucked”[/i]. All of the challenges were fun and engaging. Obviously to a different degree, but neither of them was downright bad. Well, maybe except the underwater labyrinth.
As you can imagine some things had us scratching our heads for a nice little while… but it was never because the puzzle was too convoluted to understand or because it was designed poorly. Every puzzle can be solved. We just had to figure them out first. We were actually surprised that the difficulty level does not go through a sudden spike but rather goes at a steady pace through the entire title.
I would really hurt your experience by telling you about the puzzles themselves but there is one thing you need to know:

[h1]This game is like a good psychological horror movie[/h1]
We Were Here Forever is best experienced [b]ONCE[/b]. And only once.
When I said that every puzzle can be solved, I wasn’t lying. It can be. Sadly, there is only one key to every quote unquote “riddle”. ONLY one. Everything you go through will be EXACTLY the same on all other playthroughs, to the point where after completing the game once, when my friend and I switched roles… we could complete some of the puzzles without even communicating. Memory alone was enough to lead us straight through them.

Is it a bad thing that the game can be completed only once? I don’t believe it is. But that is a one step back from the previous titles. In other entries of the series the roles that you take were distinct enough from one another to keep you invested into a second playthrough. After completing WWHF once you probably will never start this game ever again. Is it… a problem though? I’d say that the longer time it takes to complete the We Were Here Forever makes up for the fact that you’re better off playing it only once.

125271896.review:
[h1]This new We Were Here game is the best one yet ! [/h1]

If you’re not familiar with the We Were Here games, they are coop puzzle games, think escape rooms but in video game form. 

The graphics have improved, I think they are way better in this title, a lot of attention seems to have gone to the atmosphere, lighting and details.

One of the biggest change is that roles are not assigned from start to finish anymore ! Anytime a puzzle splits you up, it could have been either one of us on each side. And moreover many puzzles allow you to just switch with your partner mid-puzzle. I also like the fact that we spend less time without seeing each other at all even if separated by a barrier of some kind.

I also would say the quality has improved overall, we encountered less bugs than in previous titles.

We still chose to use discord rather than the in-game voice, but at this point we’re just too used to not using the talkies.

While the story of the game is better than the previous ones, I didn’t like the ending of that one. [spoiler]It felt rushed and gimmicky.[/spoiler]

This game is again a bit longer than its predecessor, sadly that maybe because of the “walking simulator” parts of it where you just need to get from point A to B with nothing much happening.

Even if it can still be improved on, I want to reiterate this is the best We Were Here game to this day and I hope Total Mayhem Games keeps making more !

136259582.review:
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38888018-United-Critics/] Please follow [b]United Critics[/b] for quality reviews[/url]

[h1]Bring a coat and bring a friend[/h1]
We Were Here Forever is a beautiful exploring, action adventure, puzzle, Co-op only, escape room game as it is the last Sequel of the “We Were Here” series.
The whole game has in complete six chapters and it takes around 10 hours to complete, more or less. It all depends on the players and how good they are at puzzles.
The game is about communicating. Each player gets a walkie in the beginning to be able and speak with the other player. As all walkies work, only one person can speak at a time and the player has to hold down the button to speak.

The two players has to make their way through a ton of obstacles, made of puzzles. Each player will have their own walkway, so to say. And will have the answer for the other player in a clue of an icon, or simply a lever that will open a gate or door for the other player.
At some points, the players will be able to work together at the same place but most of the time they will be split up. For certain tasks it requires both players to help in either: moving a bookshelf or pulling a lever.

[h1]The Game of The Play[/h1]
As the game starts, both the players will wake up in some mushroom prison. They will find walkies laying in their cell and discover that the cell doors are unlocked. The players will see that they weren’t in the same room as their cells were in and has to start looking for which door that’s unlocked.
After finding their way to a tunnel, they will walk upon their first puzzle in the game. Where one player has to tell the other some symbols that they see on a wall behind some metal bars, as the other player just has to pull a lever to open the first players door.

When reaching the point of where the players are able to obtain the torch they will shortly after stumble upon some metal bars that keeps them apart but atleast lets the players meet.
The players will then find two levers for each players that they have to pull down together to open a spiked door that will lead them to an abandoned mine but also used to be a home. Who’s? we don’t know, but we do know that this brings more puzzles.
Once again the two players will be split apart and can use a basket to travel items or keys over to the other to be able and unlock some objects to get new items or unlock more of the area to get deeper into the puzzle.
At times both players has to be on the same side or even switch side depending on if one is overthinking about the puzzle and unable to look at it from another perspective from their side. So his companion has to take over and see if he can explain or understand the puzzle themselves.

Each chapter has a completely different puzzle, so its never the same and won’t get boring that easily over time while playing. Though the mind can get fried from all the puzzles.
In fact each chapter has its own worlds or places with total new puzzles and new areas for both players.
The game has it set so there is a player 1 and player 2, the choosing of who’s who can be made in the main menu before starting the game.
Depending if your player 1 or player 2, only gives you different tasks and achievements after completing different puzzles.
Each player will see their own area when split up. So they will have to try and find a common ground/object or puzzle in their area that might give any clues or ability to unlock further into the game.

The areas or biomes that the players will see under their journey are underground mines, Some kind of torture games, the ruins of rockbury castle and town, the rockbury church, Underwater laboratory, the riddle’s play box and much more under the journey. There is big and small areas with different amounts of detailing, and every place you visit will be a new view for the eyes and mind.

[b]Spoiler[/b]
[spoiler]For the last game sequel of the series they had to give it a sad end. After the players destroys the castle, the church demolishes to bits. Making them fall down into the sea beneath.
Both players will swim towards a light that’s hanging from a wooden pole on a small raft that sadly only can fit one player.
The players can choose from either saving their friend and sacrificing themselves or getting saved by their friend but loosing them aswell. One man keeps his life as the other sinks to the freezing bottom of the sea, when out of nowhere a cargo ship arrives to the rescue.
Only one player survives, but at what cost...[/spoiler]

[h1]Visual & Audio[/h1]
[b]Visuals[/b]

[u]Game Textures and lights[/u]
The visuals and surrounding in the game are quite beautiful and are very well done. The ground and objects doesn’t collide into one and other and the small detailing in every little corner. It’s just a good-looking game that also makes it more fun to play.
At the beginning of the game, the shading in the tunnels/corridors had bright spots in the corners up by the roof.
Where it should be darker it’s just some brighter small light. As if it is cracks in the stones with some kind of light coming from inside of nowhere.

The texture quality of the game makes no disappointments, anywhere you look you will see how beautiful the game really is. The smooth combinations and perfect size and color fit for the objects around on the worlds. Adding the small details to the game just gives it a little extra without the player thinking about it, they just feel it and see it while exploring the world and solving the puzzles.

[u]Game Animations[/u]
Along through the chapters I saw the animation for everything around and for the actions we did. Pulling levers, going with rides, breaking stuff. It all went so smooth and no problem in sight with anything.
The cutscenes runs fantastically and the moving animation of objects and players, like bridges or mechanisms and the puppeteer/the Riddler.

[b]Audio[/b]
[u]Background Music[/u]
The music for the game doesn’t get boring. It changes along with the progress that happens in the game and depending on situation, the music will change.

[u]Voice actors[/u]
The voice acting in the game is quite stunning, The passion and emotion putted into the characters. Beside the Castle/King’s voice actor, his voice sounds deeper but its missing the power and emotion in it. Its like he’s just saying the words with a deeper voice and not speaking the words, expressing them.

[u]Sound effects[/u]
The sound effects in the game have been specially made for each object, for example: The crackling old wood or heavy stone grinding against the same material as the object moves, falls, or grinds against something else. With the echo to make it sound like the sound travels through the area like real life and muffles the further your away from it.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
•	Always different puzzles.
•	Interesting story and lore.
•	Smooth object animations.
•	A lot of creativity.
•	Longer gameplay with more content.

[b]Cons[/b]
•	The in-game communication with the walkies isn’t that comfortable or different then just simply using, for example: Discord.
•	Sometimes the torch doesn’t want to respond to the “R” button, short time after it works.

[h1]My final little thoughts[/h1]
The game is a lot longer with more content and puzzles then the earlier games in the series. And I was having a blast while playing it. The game is a Co-op only but luckily I had my friend Hulp to the rescue for he had the game already.
We tried out the walkies in the beginning, but they didn’t do anything specific or given any extra spark to it, so we just communicated through a discord call.
I highly recommend this game but only if you do have a partner, companion, friend, or person to play with.

Rating: 9/10

143492359.review:
We Were Here Forever is a two person co-op puzzle game where you must work with a friend to figure out a variety of puzzles after (usually) being placed in two different areas (on occasion you're in the same area). One person has the role of being responsible for instructing the other person who typically has the more interactive role in solving a puzzle. These roles change/are random, so one person won't be stuck doing all the work in one playthrough. There are six different chapters, each of which has multiple subchapters, that must be solved this way, using clues that are in each area.

Overall, I found this game quite fun. It's a little unclear what you're supposed to do when you first start, but you can generally figure it out by clicking around and communicating what you're seeing to your teammate. The game glitched three separate times throughout my entire time playing it, including once in the first 15 minutes, which can add to the confusion/feeling like you're stuck (because you literally are lol). The Memento, The Illusions, and The Assembly were the best subchapters, in my opinion. 

This game is the fourth in the We Were Here series. One playthrough took ~13.5 hours and a second playthrough for achievements (switching positions) took ~2 hours. If a co-op puzzle game sounds like something you'd enjoy, I'd recommend this game, though I definitely recommend playing the original as it is free and will give you a good sense of the type of gameplay you'll be getting into. This game and the others in the series follow the original very closely, so if you enjoyed the original/second/third game, you'll likely enjoy this one too.

130218906.review:
A great game to play with a friend, some puzzles easier than others. One thing to note is that few if any of the puzzles are explained in any way, which means that you may have to figure out [i]how[/i] to even [i]do[/i] the puzzles - I don't mean how to solve the puzzle once you understand the mechanics, I mean understanding the mechanics in the first place - What to click, what's important etc.
Some of the achievements are dependant on which "side" of the puzzle you do, so you might get some more replay value of playing both sides

One thing I didn't like was the use of a voice server as opposed to peer-to-peer voice. It's understandable that the developers have chosen this path considering possible hassle or issues with port-forwarding and such, but I'd much prefer at least having the [i]option[/i] to [b]NOT[/b] sign the EULA for the voice service. It states that "if you choose to use voice communications" or something to that effect, which is ridiculous as it's built in, a core part of the game [i]and[/i] there's no option to disable it. If you're very privacy-minded, you might want to simply use discord or steam voice instead and use windows 10 settings to not allow the game access to your mic.

With that being said, very much a great puzzle game, gave me and my buddy about 10-12 hours of enjoyment, confusion, a-ha (and sometimes "ah man I'm an idiot") moments. Some frustration aswell, but not really from anything the game did wrong aside from the above criticism. Definitively worth the price of 200 NOK (approx €20) I paid for it, when it was on a 20% sale. Probably worth it up to €25 as well, as one of the [i]very few[/i] true co-op games made recently.

I just realized I might be a little bit of a sadist because this is my favorite game! Yes we had fun, we lost our freaking minds, and it was an absolute treat for the co-op and puzzle lovers like myself, who have played the previous games of the series! 

The game had a HELL of an improvement. The visuals, models and environment had the biggest glow up of the century, and I dare to say specific locations are really breathtaking! The soundtrack was really good, I have two favorites; the voice acting and animation is all spot on, making the cutscenes and game very immersive with the classic We Were Here feel. They did a great job tying up loose ends from the previous games too (for the lore lovers). Finally the secondary characters have a face to be associated with, and they went all out with the antagonist and player models and animations, we can even see our own feet.

I think this is THE must-play of the series, as overall it is the coup the grâce (really wish they'd continue) and THE LONGEST yet, so obviously worth the money. The rest really depends on you, the synergy between you and your partner! Try to not lose your minds much!

Puzzles.
As always, the puzzles are brilliant. The We were here series is one of those series where the puzzles are made in a very interesting way. BUT, of course, there were a couple of absurd puzzles, the solution of which was made “randomly” by getting into the correct solution, or by accidentally doing the right action.

Plot.
There is no plot as such with any semantic meaning; the emphasis is more on gameplay and puzzle solving. A typical ending at the end, where players have to make a choice (no spoilers, but those who have completed the previous parts will understand what I mean).
Gameplay.
The game is quite nicely made on the Unity engine, but there are still some bugs that are known to the developers and it is unclear whether they will fix them, or maybe it is not necessary at all. Freezing on the initial screen can be eliminated by replacing the line in the config file, in my opinion there is nothing complicated, knowing this problem, release a bug fix, but oh well. There are some bugs, but they are not critical for a comfortable passage.
P.s.
I would like to talk about a typical co-op playthrough - I read a lot of reviews about how people fought/divorced over the game, etc., I can’t say anything about my experience, there was no swearing or anything else, the game went smoothly and even with humor.

I definitely recommend We Were Here Forever for playing together with a friend!

116370993.review: The 'We Were Here' game series started with a small game where one person was in a room filled with answers, and another was in a room filled with questions. To see the idea of explorers from throughout the series working together, seeing familiar faces or really just familiar walki-talkies is a delight. This game series and We Were Here Forever specifically has left a lasting dent on my mind, and has quenched my thirst for coop puzzle solving. The idea of puzzles that have no given rules, until you figure them out, and the necessity for describing sights and sounds that the other player may not hear or see strengthens bonds and gives a good laugh. We Were Here Forever allows the player to get hints. This means that everything you need to solve puzzles, and get help solving them comes right with the game; No searching google for answers. Overall We Were Here Forever has blown my expectations out of the water. To see a game series start out fairly simple and grow into this amazing game makes me proud to be a member of its community and makes me excited for the future of We Were Here or any branching series made by these great Devs.

115678054.review:
We Were Here Forever is a great 2 player online co-op puzzle game that relies on communicating with your partner.

Best part of the series yet! The storytelling has been improved with cinematics. While there is an overarching story, this game works as a standalone because the focus on the story is about setting the mood for the next puzzle. The puzzles are less abstract, more intuitive and there are more of them. This doesn't mean they became easy, there will still be plenty of moments where you are stuck trying to figure out a puzzle, but they won't be as frustrating to solve. As usual, the puzzles work by exchanging information with each other and figuring them out with logic, some of which reset after a few attempts or by the timer running out.

The game currently has some issues that should be easily fixed. At the end of the octopus puzzle, I was still stuck in the chair while my partner could progress to the next puzzle. Loading up the save for the next puzzle gave a black screen to whoever was hosting. Luckily we could work around this by replaying the octopus puzzle because of the nice chapter select. In some of the bigger puzzles, the FPS takes a big hit, not just on my mediocre PC, but on my partner's beefy PC as well.

Overall, this is a fun time, it's more and better!

For achievement hunters:
Play the game from both sides and reach both endings, has a chapter select. If one of you has a weaker PC, make sure your partner is loaded in the game or you'll have to replay that part for the achievement to pop.

115324240.review: Very fun and engaging puzzle game for 2, and a massive improvement from the previous games in the series. TotalMayhem keep outdoing themselves.

115516882.review:
We Were Here Forever is the refined crescendo the series has been building up to in past iterations. And one of my favourites.
The previous games established much of the basic premise and puzzle structures, but were clearly still unrefined and had a lot of things that detracted from the nicer aspects. But We Were Here Forever fixes all of those detractors and more.

This review will not contain spoilers, but if you want a TL'DR; the game is superb and an example of co-operative puzzle games and instantly one of my favorite puzzle games period.
Regardless, time to get into the nitty gritty.

---- Visual & Audio ----

Put simply, I love the design of this world. The art style and level design are not only incredibly beautiful, but incredibly fitting thematically. The world feels simultaneously magical like straight out of a fairytale, but also still makes total sense to navigate and explore. The detail in designs is fantastic and the variety of areas and environments is diverse and at times breathtaking. Visually the game is a master class of using effective design decisions to showcase the story and the world as you navigate it.

Levels are unique and feel refreshing to look at, while the puzzles are integrated organically into the surrounding world. With lighting and use of props the world highlights what it needs to to make navigating intuitive, and also does an effective job of conveying emotion and tension.

The sound design is clear and beautiful. The music of the game is gorgeous, and the voice acting of the characters has no right being as good as it is for a puzzle game. The Jester's voice actor in particular brought their absolute best, and I was continually impressed by their performance in various parts of the game.
If it were up to me, they'd get an award.

The use of cutscenes and animations, while subdued and not excessive, is very effective. And the visual and audio design of those cutscenes is fantastic and truly left an impression on me.
All of this combines into a style that I truly think will stand the test of time and will still inspire joy in people years from now. And all the kudos to the artists and sound designers, as well as the voice cast.

---- Puzzles ----

The puzzles are plentiful, and yet incredibly unique. The puzzles didn't repeat themselves past their welcome, and were always intuitively designed to fit into the environment and to be easily approachable and understandable. As well as requiring you to move around whilst doing so, making it feel more kinetic and memorable than simply staring at a piece of paper or a machine. Offering a nice variety of both difficulty and type of puzzle means that you're not likely to get bored at lack of new things to try or puzzles to figure out. So if you want to be truly tested on various kinds of puzzles, this is the game for you without a doubt.

The communication between co-op partners is intuitive and encourages you to learn to communicate more effectively. The puzzles are designed in a way where you can describe the situation very well once you wrap your head around it, and all it often takes is for your partner to say one thing to set the light bulbs off in your head. In addition to this many levels involve changing around the perspective between you and your partner, as well as converging your paths only to separate them again.
This all makes for a far more organic feeling and free environment, making it feel less constrained and boxed in than previous We Were Here titles, or many other puzzle games.

Communication in-game is done through a simple but effective voice chat system incorporating a walkie talkie. (Though granted I played it with a friend over Discord, but it's nice to have for those that don't have that option or want the extra immersion.) Communication is key, and this is a good way to practice how well you and a friend can sync up and learn to convey information.

The puzzles never got on my nerves, though you might of course be different in this regard, but I was simply enjoying my time far too much. And overall the puzzles are fantastic and deal with so many unique concepts and gameplay methods that I can't help but applaud the developers.

---- Gameplay ----

Playing the game is incredibly intuitive, navigating is easy and straightforward and the game does a fantastic job of introducing the environments and puzzles to you. The tutorial the game begins with is very effective at conveying all the basic skills you'll need to get started, and once the game proper begins it's a steady curve of improvement and challenge from one location to the next.

The gameplay is solid and functions as expected with the exception of a few slight bugs here and there, but nothing game breaking as far as I or my friend experienced. The controls are responsive and the way you interact with the environment or the puzzles are all simple to grasp on a technical level. The levels are designed in a way to make them quite easy to wrap your head around and figure out where everything is, with clever uses of memorable landmarks as well as good use of lines of sight.

This also extends to your partner, and locating each other is usually not too difficult. And if you have trouble figuring out where you are, just describe what you see and turn on your torch and finding each other is quick and easy. The co-op aspect of gameplay works without issues and I encountered no problems that prevented us from progressing during the entire duration of the game. Connection seems a non-issue (though that's to be expected) with the only slight desync happening for some animations.

Overall the game is very accessible even if you're fairly new to first person games, and wrapping your head around the ordeal won't take too long to figure out.

---- Technicals ----

The game runs flawlessly, with one notable exception. Transitions from level to level often cause lag and choppiness for some amount of time as the levels load in. However, it subsides quickly and once the game has finished loading everything in, all problems are gone. Performance is rock solid beyond these load moments, and I had no issues playing the game what-so-ever.

The controls are responsive and the menus are a vast improvement over previous titles in the series, and the UI is well designed and clean allowing you to take everything in properly.
A lot of people kept referring to a bugged puzzle in the graveyard section of the game, but we encountered no bug in said area. Not sure if we simply got lucky, or if there's something else going on. But overall there was no real hindrance at any point to our playthrough or enjoyment, and overall the experience was pretty flawless.

---- Closing thoughts ----

Ultimately it comes down to one simple fact. Do you like puzzles?
If you do, then this game is undoubtedly worth checking out, and a great way to spend some quality time with a friend. However it is worth noting that as a co-op only puzzle game.
I would recommend either bringing along a friend, or finding suitable players on the community page or through other means. Since it definitely is a commitment, albeit a fairly small one.

Overall We Were Here Forever is one of my favorite puzzle games of all time. Up there with games like Portal or Talos Principle. A unique and refreshing experience with beautiful designs throughout, a fantastic style, absolutely stellar voice acting and audio, and some of the most breathtaking and varied environments.

The developers have refined their talent, and have put out a game that truly is one of the best of its kind.
And the amount of love and effort put into every corner of the game is undeniable.

The name of the game is incorrect, since we were only there for a couple evenings. But the game certainly makes a compelling case for why I would want to be there forever. Since it was truly a wonderful experience made with care and love.

And I'd be lying if I said I didn't want much, much more of it.

We Were Here Forever is a cooperative adventure puzzle game for 2 players. It’s a game where you truly cooperate, not just play together with your friend and do your own thing. In order to solve the puzzles, you need to communicate and describe to each other what you see or hear to get the whole picture of the puzzle.

It’s very entertaining. All puzzles are different from each other so it never feels repetitive. This is also amazing because even though it’s already their fourth We Were Here game, they can still come up with new fresh ideas for great puzzles.

This is not a game you want to watch before playing. For the best experience I recommend going in knowing nothing about the puzzles and solutions. I also recommend starting with their first game We Were Here, which is for free and is very short. This way you will know if you like this kind of gameplay and then you can decide if you want to buy the rest or not. 

There might still be bugs in the game. We experienced one during our playthrough and honestly it was very hard to know that it’s unsolvable. We were lucky to find out before we started pulling our hair out.

100% recommended. We Were Here games are getting better with each game made and we are already looking forward to their next game!

115246662.review:
[h1] 2 MIN Video Review [/h1]
https://youtu.be/iEjbeaUJMEQ

[h1] Written Review [/h1]
We were here forever is a great new addition to the fantastic co-op series.

[b] If you are new to the franchise: [/b] 
The games are asymmetrical co-op games, that have you work together over walkie-talkies in order to solve puzzles. You are rarely in the same room, and get glimpses of lore as you explore atmospheric castle set pieces.

[b] If you've played the previous games: [/b] 
You get exactly what you'd expect here. Forever is more of the same, but not in a stale way. Some puzzle styles will feel familiar, while others bring fun and fresh ideas to the table. It's a great mix.

A lot of the time, you will be visiting unique looking areas that are in strong contrast to the drab bricked dungeons we're used to in the series. And we get a lot more story and cutscenes in this game, for those itching to learn more about the world. It's done well, and doesn't feel like it gets in the way of pacing.

The graphics are charming, and the music always enhances the mood. I got sucked into the environment, and got spooked or fascinated many times.

For the most part, the puzzles are pretty tough, but you will figure them out with perseverance. However, like in past games, there are a few puzzles that really had us scratching our heads for a long time. The game can get quite tough at times, with some time-sensitive puzzles, or others that have you juggle a ton of information in your head at once.

[b]Conclusion:[/b]
In the end, if you enjoyed the series up to this point, I think you will have fun with this game too. I think the games have been growing in terms of quality and length with every new installment. And if you haven't played the series yet, and enjoy asymmetrical co-op games, (and don't mind possibly losing your friends over puzzle misunderstandings), then give the series a try!

122986579.review:
Escape or die trying.

Story:

Like the previous three We Were Here games, it puts you into the shoes of two explorers who awaken deep underneath Castle Rock. Suddenly you're freed from your cells and this begins your journey to escape, but you find that the stakes are much higher than ever before.

Even though there's much more story this time around, it again takes a backseat to the puzzles and such. However this time around a lot of the puzzles have lore written into the puzzles, so while you're solving the complex enigmas thrown at you, it tells you the story of the castle and what led to it's downfall. However a good chunk of it is information that we learned from the previous games, although with added explanations. 

The only major negative is that the story ends on a very sequel bait ending which feels incredibly abrupt considering the journey to the end is much longer this time around. The fact that we're likely pretty far away from the next entry, I feel like they should have went with something else.  

Graphics

From game to game the graphical leap has been impressive to say the least. What started as a simplistic looking game has now turned into a really visually stunning game. The environments you visit throughout are grander in scale and in visual fidelity.

Some of the moments you witness are actually jaw dropping and the developers have totally outdid themselves. Of course there are still a few minor issues like some textures being re-used from the previous game and some of the models looking low quality, but they are so minor they do not detract from everything else.

Audio:

Out of a game full of strengths this is probably it's biggest weakness. First of all let's start with the music. The music throughout the series has always been pretty weak for me and I'm glad to say that this one has the best soundtrack hands down. There's plenty of great new tracks that help build atmosphere, get your blood pumping etc. 

However I've noticed that quite a lot of the games sound effects and even some minor tracks have been re-used from the previous games. Again since the development team is so small, I feel like I can excuse this, but I wish that they wouldn't rely on re-used assets as much as they do. Also the tradition of so bad it's good voice acting is still here front and center.

Gameplay:

We Were Here Forever follows the same basic formula as the previous three games in the series. You and your co-op partner have walkie talkies and use them to communicate to solve increasingly difficult puzzles. So let's talk about the puzzles. 

The puzzles start off simple enough, but quickly become incredibly complex. The scope of the game is much larger in scale and because of it, the puzzles seem scarier before you comprehend everything that goes into solving it. That's not to say that they are simple, they range from simplistic, to pretty difficult. 

There's not many puzzles this time around that can cause death, but they are traded with more puzzles that take longer to complete cause they force you to walk around a large area, flipping different mechanisms. For some these puzzles might seem much more tedious than what was in the other games, purely due to the size of them, but I felt like that was one of this games strength. 

My biggest gripe with the puzzles is the a poor difficulty scale. It felt like each puzzle in the previous games gradually got harder and harder with some minor breathing room puzzles, Forever has puzzles that are incredibly difficult, followed up by incredibly easy puzzles and vice versa, however since basically all of them are incredibly fun to solve. 

Verdict:

The fourth entry in the series is by far the most complex and fun. Every game has been a vast improvement over the previous and if there is a number 5 I can't wait to see what crazy puzzles will the devs come up with next. If you want to play something with a friend and have nothing to do, you can't go wrong with these games, so go and check it out.

Final Rating:
9/10

Pros:
+ Puzzles are the best yet
+ Visuals are stunning 
+ Interesting lore 

Cons:
- Difficulty scaling is all over the place 
- Ending is sequel bait

If you liked this review please consider joining https://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog and https://steamcommunity.com/groups/ImperialReviews

115882573.review:
Me and my partner played the first 3 games together, and then realised the fourth one was releasing soon, we knew we had to get the completionist on the first three before smashing out this one. We were so pumped to get this game the second it came out, and how could we resist that juicy 10% off sale?

Now the game, I will not lie has been a buggy mess, and it was especially worse when there was no Australian servers for the first few days. However the devs were really onto it and fixed everything as soon as they could, I know my partner wasn't taking any of the shit the first few days but then we both realised something in our hearts. We are the smartest, and the funniest, and the best, and the only ones who should be together in such desperate measures.

The best part about smashing out a game so early is that there is no walkthrough, meaning that everything we did was legitty on our titties, which leads me to believe that our brain patterns have been altered, what if we are both genetically engineered to begin with?

I remember playing the first game several times and not knowing about how deep the lore actually went, but when my partner came along for the first time, the one I was destined to be with, I just knew that the one I had been waiting for had finally come, and I opened my eyes for the first time to see how good the lore actually is. As I write this review, I know my partner wants more of this, whether its part of the same series or not, as long as we keep getting more.

I have a bad feeling however that this is the last game of the We Were Here series, they say that all good things must come to an end, however I do know one thing is for sure. This door closes for me, but it has made way for another one to open, the path that I must walk with my partner. And I know that I definitely won't be treading off this path, no matter how long it is I will always stand by my partners side, this series has prepared us for the toughest obstacles that we can now face on our own.

I was asked several times by a few of my friends, "Who is this mysterious partner you keep referring to? And why are they so perfect?" Perhaps one day I may reveal this partner, however all I can say for now, is that my partner was a very unlikely one, and that I would have never foreseen being with them like this.

Just the thought of me and my partner having been through so much together, seeing each other leave one behind, as one of us turns our backs and keeps walking, getting separated and coming back to each other. I do know that if I was ever met with a choice similar to the series in the real world, I know what I would pick. But I would not think of them as the "Worst Friend Forever". After all, I was always first to get left behind or die each time, and I don't plan on changing the outcome.

All that matters to me is my partners happiness, but how can I make someone happy when they are faced with such a difficult choice? If the time ever comes, I hope that my partner will understand what I have done, and that everything I did was to make this special someone happy. I do know that our ups heavily outweigh our downs, and that is enough for me. I sleep easy at night knowing that the choices I have made for my partner will keep a smile on their face.

To think that in the little time I had with my partner, it feels like we have known each other for years, decades, centuries, hell even eons. There will always be a place in my heart for my partner, whether we drift apart in the future, or if we end up staying together. I know damn well that I prefer the latter of that sentence, but I will keep this up as a memory, so that I may never forget the amazing times I had with my partner. We will tell everyone indeed that We, Were, Here.

Let that blaze across the realms for eras...

115776336.review:
[i][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/35145066/] My review page.[/url][/i] 
[i][url=https://www.twitch.tv/nightserg] Follow me on twitch![/url][/i] 

[h1]The gist of it:[/h1]
We Were Here Forever the final(?) entry in the series has finally launched but is it as good as the previous ones? No, it's much better! It's a fantastic puzzle-focused coop game and we need more. 

👍 [u]The good parts:[/u]
+Level design and the environments.
+The puzzles ofc.
+Much better story-telling than previous ones.

👎[u]The bad parts:[/u]
-Minor bugs that made us restart an entire chapter.
-Some puzzles like the final one were super easy. 

[h1]Story[/h1]
If you played the previous ones, you know there's some story about a king and how he did some bad things and some jester but it never made much sense. Luckily the story finally becomes much more focused and clear as there are finally story cutscenes with dialogue and everything. 

You are back at Castle Rock trying to go through the Jester and King's endless puzzles but this time something changes. You manage to escape and find yourselves outside the castle where you find the plans of some rebel families that stood up to the King. I won't spoil more but this time around it feels like there's some actual lore behind everything as well as a proper ending, well except for one minor thing which I did not like at the end. Don't think there was an alternative to it. 

In any case, this is not some story that will blow your mind or make you emotional, the series was never about that, but I appreciated that they did gave us something better than previous games in this regard. 

Story rating: 7.5/10

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Just like the previous games, We Were Here Forever is a coop puzzle-focused adventure game where you and your partner have to progress through really tough puzzles in order to escape Castle Rock and its vicinities. 

You'll have parts where you can switch back and forth puzzles with your partner which helps in figuring out certain puzzles but there are also parts where you are both stuck on your selected side and you'll have to coordinate via voice on how to advance forward. 

Most puzzles will require you both to really think hard but there are a few such as the final one where they are extremely easy. The last puzzle was a bit disappointing, I was expecting something much more with an ompfh. Overall as I don't want to spoil you with what the game will throw at you in terms of puzzles, there are going to be some path-blocking ones, there's a cooking simulator one, and so many more. They are all unique and different from each other, not once will you get bored. There's also a hint system tho it's mostly useless as it only tells you how to start figuring out the puzzles which anyone with an average IQ will do.  

Fun and tough game and I'm curious what the devs can cook up next, assuming they'll still do coop/puzzle games. It's a rare genre so more is always welcome. Perhaps something sci-fi next time such as Portal 2 coop? 

Gameplay rating: 8.5/10

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Ah, voice acting, finally you won't have to look at weird cutscenes without a voice and surprisingly it's really well acted. 

The soundtrack is great, no complaints here, and I loved that there was a music type of puzzle as well as one with figuring out words out of sounds. Really well done. 

Other than that, the sound effects such as the atmospheric ones and whatever else are generally quite good, no complaints.

Audio rating: 8/10

[h1]Graphics, performance and tech analysis[/h1]
I'll start with the bad real quick which were some bugs that forced us to restart an entire chapter but the devs said it had to do with servers so who knows. There were other minor ones as well but nothing worth talking about. 

What's really impressive this time around is the scope of the levels and their design. Long gone are the days of small rooms with puzzles, this time around everything around you feels masterfully crafted like a huge metroidvania-like map filled with puzzles, minus the backtracking. The way the levels and the puzzles are placed and how they work well with each other is perfect. They outdid themselves and I can't wait for what they do next.

As for the game performance, it's a bit iffy at times, frames can drop even on a high-end pc to 50s but overall it runs smooth.

Graphics, performance and tech analysis score: 8/10

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you're a fan of the series then I don't have to tell you to go buy it and if you're new I suggest playing them all tho not mandatory since We Were Here Forever can be easily played even as your first game. 

[h1]Final score: 8/10[/h1]

115613924.review:
Overall, just disappointing. I won't call it bad - you've got your two player puzzling and it works - but for the final(?) game in the series, the one with the longest development time and the one with the highest price tag, it feels a big step backwards from its predecessors.

It's hard to nail down exactly why, but I think it feels too tame, as if they approached this one with the mindset of really making a commercial game (the original was a student project IIRC), and were worried of scaring away players. There's no tension of having to solve a puzzle before you die to some encroaching hazard (increasingly-panicked chatter on the walkie talkies that can't both receive and transmit at the same time was genuinely one of my favourite parts of the previous games), and the puzzles are so self-contained - no more running around trying to figure out what you should be doing, instead you're typically sealed in a small area with only the puzzle elements, leaving the experience feeling overly-curated. "Here's the next puzzle, solve it using these parts," goes the game, "I'll be waiting to escort you to the next puzzle."

On top of that, the puzzles themselves feel worse than in the previous games. Too many of the puzzles have both players simultaneously interacting with the same elements, leading to most of them ending with one person figuring it out and dictating everything to the other player. They feel more like single-player puzzles where the second player only exists to physically enter their half of the solution and maybe answer specific questions about details you know are there but can't see the exact details of.
The few asymmetrical puzzles beyond that seem to blitz through the interesting asymmetrical puzzle solving and go straight to the execution. Rather than collaboratively working out a solution you tend to see what you're supposed to do straight away followed by however much time of just repeating information back and forth, or worse one player is left really bored as their half just has so much less to do.
Really, the asymmetrical part of the co-op puzzle solving was what made the series unique, and to see it stray away from that feels like they've squandered what made the games what they are.

The game's longer than the older ones. There's more story as well, which may be hit-or-miss. I couldn't care less for it as it was the series's mechanics that held my interest, but the friend I played through them with was interested in the story. Either way, the individual puzzle quality has suffered for both. There were a couple I came out of thinking 'that one was pretty decent', but there's nothing memorable in there.

As I said at the start, I can't outright call it bad, but the development time and the price point both set expectations that the game consistently failed to meet. For half the price I likely would have been satisfied with the experience, but at full price it's just too bland.
115613924.developer_response: Hi there, thanks for your feedback! We are sorry to hear that you feel this way. A little thing I do want to add is that this is not our final game! :) We can't say much yet, but we do have great plans for the future.

The puzzles were largely fun, and interesting. However, the game suffers from three major pitfalls:

First, the pacing is absolutely awful. All of the cutscenes that move character between areas take 3x as long as they should, and a lot of the game feels like they artificially extended the playtime through pointless walking and waiting.

And second, too many of the puzzles had an imbalance of information, to the point where one person was doing 90% of the thinking and problem solving, and the other person was just bored waiting until they could test the possible solutions.

Lastly, the optimization was terrible. I have a VERY solid PC, and the underwater level was still a permanent ~20 fps the entire time we were there. This is pretty unacceptable from a studio that has already released multiple titles.

Overall, it was still a decent game, but because of these issues it left a bad taste in my mouth and so I feel the negative review is warranted.

154354251.review:
[h1] We Were Here Forever: A Puzzling Co-op Adventure That Went Beyond Expectations![/h1]

Alright, let me spill the beans on my recent plunge into the fourth gem of the We Were Here series, aptly named "We Were Here Forever." Now, I'm not one to sugarcoat things, but if you're into co-op puzzles, this game is your jackpot. It's not the first rodeo for Total Mayhem Games, and boy, does it show.

Picture this: a co-op puzzler where you and your partner are thrown into a labyrinth of tricky enigmas. Sometimes you're side by side, pulling levers and deciphering codes, while at other times, you're scattered, sharing crucial information over trusty walkie-talkies. Oh, did I mention there's a sinister jester lingering in the background? It adds a touch of mystery, but let's be real, the puzzles are the stars here.

Now, the story takes a bit of a backseat, and that's perfectly fine. We're not here for a cinematic masterpiece; we're here to flex those brain muscles. The narrative carries on from the previous games, which is a nice touch for returning players. Still, for me, it wasn't exactly a gripping novel—more like a side note to the real action.

But let's cut to the chase—the puzzles. We Were Here Forever doesn't just bring puzzles; it brings a masterclass in intricate design. From memory challenges to quick reactions, and logical thinking, each puzzle throws a different flavor at you, always rewarding when cracked. And communication? More critical than ever. There were moments my partner and I felt utterly stumped, only to realize we missed a tiny detail. It's a testament to how every detail matters, and talking your way through is the key to success.

Now, not all puzzles were sunshine and rainbows. Some were needlessly tricky or dragged on a tad too long. One involved hitting colored switches, and trust me, it sounded way better on paper. But let's not dwell on the hiccups because, trust me, the good far outweighs the bad.

This game is a beefy adventure, clocking over ten hours easily. The longer runtime meant a few puzzles got under my skin, but it also meant there were plenty more that I absolutely loved. And the world, my friend, it's more extensive than ever. Castle Rock has evolved, offering diverse areas that pop visually. Even though some places felt a bit similar, the breathtaking sights kept me hooked.

Now, it's tricky to spill all the beans without spoilers, but here's the gist: We Were Here Forever is a concoction of ingenious puzzles and seamless co-op communication. It's Total Mayhem Games flexing their muscles, and boy, does it pay off. The co-op puzzling concept, you'd think it'd get stale by the fourth entry. Surprise, surprise—it's better than ever.

So, among a couple of annoying puzzles and a bit of a stretch in certain areas, We Were Here Forever stands tall, offering a gripping co-op puzzle experience. If you're into brain-teasers and fancy a unique multiplayer ride, give it a shot. 

When you finally nail that puzzle with your partner? It's Pure satisfaction.

156211039.review:
Right off the bat, I have to say first that I EXTREMELY enjoyed the whole series~. Thus: I suggest you play the other 3 games before this one!
They try to hint and/or even bring back some puzzles from the other 3 games, but with changes of course so it isn't exactly the same at all. But for me, this was a really nice little 'easter eggs' and just nice reference and connection to their other games.

BUT! Not just for that: There is a story~! The first game didn't have it much at first to me but one hint, but by game two, and really 3, you start to learn of a developing story that I thought fit very will for the game's atmosphere. And this game, 'Forever', brings the story to a conclusions- or does it~?- and more explainational depth.


Overall: The story I thought was really well done, and yet will still leave you questioning a few things but I think is intentional. Either for a future game, or just to make you wonder forever (just as the title hah). The actual 'gameplay' mechanics I think honestly degraded, *just slightly* though. I felt they could of just stuck with game 3's keybindings and all, but nothing was annoying or confusing to say the least. We still played with no problems. Graphics: Just better of course following the other games showing their progress. And the Puzzles. . ho boy.

Puzzles: I will say, started off great and wracks your brain to think with your partner- although me and my partner were rather too smart and flew through pretty fast but still enough to satisfy thinking hard enough :3. But.. the later half or near endgame, I will say became VERY confusing. Two puzzles had me and partner confused and lost on where to even start. We're pretty sure one puzzle we just 'accidentally' completed, as we never really figured out what the puzzle was. But overall 80% of the puzzles were clear on what you needed to figure out after some thinking, and was really fun and unique each time :3.

Pros:
+ Graphics nice
+ Puzzles you really will need to think and have patience on.
+ Awesome, unique story!
+ Lengthy enough to feel engaging and not too short at all.

Con:
- Two puzzles really give you no idea where or how to start and what to do.
- Half the puzzles are pretty one sided on working together to help, but + they do balance back and forth on this position for each player.
- Sadly may not be replayable even with new partner as you'll already understand the puzzles after.


* This series was fun :3 and would love to play it again, but the puzzles are not randomized T^T. Even if I returned years later, I'm sure i'll at least remember what to do, even if not how to solve it instantly. But I still LOVED the experience and had a great partner to join me on the adventure beginning to end :3.

154656398.review:
I used to like these games. The one bad thing about them was the time limit in certain challenges. And it's still a huge issue in this one. Would have really appreciated a possibility to disable the time limits. This is not only a huge annoyance for people who just want to have a chill playing sesh with a friend or loved one, but also a serious accessibility issue. These games have no accessibility settings at all. A real shame. 

A lot of the puzzles were really fun. Those were ones without time limits and that required us both to think about the solutions equally. Some of the puzzles however, are just unnecessarily hard. Or repetitive. For example three rounds of the same puzzle, each harder than the other. Or the other player has a lot of information and the other only little. Or there is only one possible way to complete a puzzle. I feel like this game isn't for normal couples or friends who want to have a fun gaming night anymore. Some of the puzzles require serious planning because of the time limit and that kind of serious planning takes the fun away from people who are not used to it. Time limits should be possible to disable.

TLDL: Time limits take away the fun, feels like game isn't for casual players anymore.

147736933.review:
[h1] The grand finale, yet the start for something great [/h1]

We Were here Forever is the final game in the storyline of castle rock, also not the last one. Its the longest of all games and the one I might recognize as the first game that could compete with games made by bigger studios. Hazelight for example. 

The game offers a bunch of fun and challenging puzzles and every step you make in this game feals earned. This time we get to experience different sets from castle to underwater a lot of stuff to freshen up the gameplay is included. It even has boss fights. Really for the first time you have boss fights and they are great. 

With We Were Here Forever we finally got see the outcome of a great narration giving us a satisfying end to a great series. The built up, the expection I had where filled to the brim and the game as all games plays with your emotions. 

Puzzlewise games like the big dimensional puzzle or the side scrolling one where a great expierence to make. It might be that the second game is my favorite but this is surely a good competitor for that spot. The only let down I experience is the overwhelming input some rooms and puzzles have. Were the first two games where easilier to grasp the third and this sometimes needed time understand and getting used to some rooms and puzzles. 

I did wrote some line about the lessons this game series tells. A lesson about bonding further with a friend or partner. The grand finale combines the best of all lessons. While the first focused on communication, the second strengthen collaboration and trust and the third tested your patience, the final one does everything to break you and your partners bonding. The result if withstanded is a deeper and stronger bond. 

Sometimes I wished I could rediscover those games as if I never played them before and then playing them for the first time again. Its so great to take each new person in my life to get to know them with playing the great We Were Here Series. 

I am so gratefull for those games and I hope total Mayhem can bring us more great games. I mean we got a smaller one shot set in the world of We Were Here but with this being the final new oportunities like new settings open up. I d like to see a game that kinda resembles a great Indiana Jones adventure in forgotten jungle temple or buried desert civilizations.

158665147.review:
We Were Here Forever blows every other game out of the water. The Story is a direct continuation of we were here together. Every puzzle is satisfying to complete and involves a lot of simultaneous puzzle-solving compared to just call and response puzzle solving. (Even though a good portion are call and response, it still requires at least some work on the other person's end to complete). The story is great in this game and really tells a story through puzzles as well as just having great puzzles. This game is home to my absolute favorite puzzles in the series. They have a hint system which is 90% of the time useless. They give you 3 hints per level (per person). and you can only open them 30 seconds after one another so you really think about it. But the hints are usually just "1. communicate with your partner" "2. look around for hints!" and then the third hint usually had substance. I only used hints on a few levels. It doesnt rely on hard-to-describe symbols as its only sense of difficulty and it is just a blast to play. If you want to get the complete we were here experience definitely play Forever as it avoids most of the pitfalls of the other games.

You should play we were here Together before to get the story, but before that you can play The first game and Friendship if you just wanna feel out the games without a huge time/money commitment
Not to mention that we were here forever has about 5 hours worth of playtime more than together

155320427.review:
This is a fantastic game that tragically runs like garbage. While a little clunky my computer can usually handle most intense games with not much issue, but no matter how low I make the settings this game is just a mess. Thankfully it never really interfered with any of the puzzles, but if you have a lower end computer I would be wary. 

Optimization aside, We Were Here Forever is another amazing entry to this series. The location and grandeur of the story have increased tenfold, giving the Explorers more varied and interesting places to explore. Similar to the third game there are many occasions where you and your partner can see and interact with each other, but it never really detracts from the atmosphere and puzzles. The hint system is a nice touch, though we did not use it almost at all so I can't say how helpful it was. While this game has some really fantastic puzzles and creative interactions, it also has some of my least favorite ones in the entire series. Several of them felt more lopsided than I would have liked, with one person standing around doing nothing but talking and the other person "does all the work". Despite that this is still one of my favorites of the series and it finally gives us some closure for this story. [spoiler] Even if that ending is extremely unsatisfying. I can't believe they pulled a Titanic on us sheesh [/spoiler]
